parameters: <WordWrap>\c[4]Word Wrapping\c[0] is now possible through the message system. You can enable and disable \c[4]Word Wrap\c[0] using \c[4]Plugin Commands\c[0].

<WordWrap>While using \c[4]Word Wrap\c[0], if the word is to extend past the message window's area, it will automatically go to the following line. That said, \c[4]Word Wrap\c[0] will disable the editor's line breaks and will require you to use the ones provided by the plugin:
<WordWrap>\c[4]<\c[4]br>\c[0] or \c[4]<\c[4]line break>\c[0] is text code to apply a line break. Use this before or after a part in which you wish to start a new line.

<WordWrap>Keep in mind \c[4]Word Wrapping\c[0] is mostly for message windows. However, in other places that you'd like to see \c[4]Word Wrapping\c[0], such as item descriptions, insert \c[4]<\c[4]WordWrap>\c[0] at the beginning of the text to enable it.
<WordWrap>\c[4]Word Wrapping\c[0] is now possible through the message system. You can enable and disable \c[4]Word Wrap\c[0] using \c[4]Plugin Commands\c[0].

<WordWrap>Keep in mind \c[4]Word Wrapping\c[0] is mostly for message windows. However, in other places that you'd like to see \c[4]Word Wrapping\c[0], such as item descriptions, insert \c[4]<\c[4]WordWrap>\c[0] at the beginning of the text to enable it.
By using certain text codes in your messages, you can have
the game substitute them for neat effects.
\n<Basic Text Codes>Here is a list of the text codes you may use:
\c[4]\\V[n]\c[0] \px[300]Replaced by the value of the nth variable.
\c[4]\\N[n]\c[0] \px[300]Replaced by the name of the nth actor.
\c[4]\\P[n]\c[0] \px[300]Replaced by the name of the nth party member.
\c[4]\\C[n]\c[0] \px[300]Draw the subsequent text in the nth color.
\c[4]\\{\c[0] \px[300]Increases the text size by one step.
\c[4]\\}\c[0] \px[300]Decreases the text size by one step.
Use them to enhance your messages!

You can make certain messages in your game apply wait times.\!
They\| can\| be\| slow\| or\| they\. can\. be\. quick.
\n<Wait Text Codes>Here is a list of the text codes you may use:
\c[4]\\>\c[0] \px[300]Display remaining text on same line all at once.
\c[4]\\<\c[0] \px[300]Cancel the effect that displays text all at once.
\c[4]\\^\c[0] \px[300]Do not wait for input after displaying text.
These wait effects only apply to the message window and do
You can use them to add dramatic pauses to dialogue
and spice up your game further.

Welcome to the \c[4]Royal Library\c[0]! Feel free to bask
yourself inside this giant wealth of knowledge.
Welcome to the \c[4]Royal Library\c[0]! Here on the bottom floor,
you can find information regarding the \c[6]Message Core\c[0].
On the upper floors, you can find out information
The \c[4]Name Box Window\c[0] is a new window added by the
\c[6]Message Core\c[0]. It displays any kind of text inside of it,
but is mostly used for displaying the name of whoever
is currently speaking (hence the name).\n<Name Box>
To display a \c[4]Name Box Window\c[0], use the \c[4]\\n<x>\c[0] text code.
The \c[4]Name Box Window\c[0] will automatically be fitted to have
the x text inside of it.
However, you can display the \c[4]Name Box Window\c[0] centered
above your message window with the \c[4]\\nc<x>\c[0] text code.
Or you can display it towards the right side of the screen
How you use it is entirely up to you!

You can set set the exact X and Y positions of subsequent
text to appear using the \c[4]\\px[n]\c[0] and \c[4]\\px[y]\c[0] text codes.
This let's you perform more controlled text coordinates.
With it, you can avoid using spaces and keep indented

This let's you perform more controlled text coordinates.

You can change the width of text outlines through the
\c[4]\\ow[x]\c[0] text code. \ow[8]It will appear something like this.
Should you fancy changing the outline color, you can use the
\c[4]\\oc[x]\c[0] text code. \oc[4]The colors used depend on the window skin.
You can change the width of text outlines through the
\c[4]\\ow[x]\c[0] text code. \ow[8]It will appear something like this.
Should you fancy changing the outline color, you can use the
\c[4]\\oc[x]\c[0] text code. \oc[4]The colors used depend on the window skin.
You can change the font used by a message mid-message
The \c[4]\\fs[x]\c[0] text code allows you to change the font size.
The \c[4]\\fn<n>\c[0] text code allows you to change the font name.
This way, you can switch to \fn<Courier New>different fonts\fr on the go.
The text codes \c[4]\\fb\c[0] and \c[4]\\fi\c[0] allow you to toggle the
If you wish to reset the font settings of the message to
the default settings, use the \c[4]\\fr\c[0] text code.

Sometimes, when there is too much text to go through
and you wish to fast forward through, you can press the
for this sample project is the \c[4]Page Down\c[0] key.\n<Fast Forward>
It's useful for those cases where the player may have
pressed the \c[4]OK\c[0] button too many times and accidentally
talked to an event again that may have too much text
that the player has no interest in rereading.\n<Fast Forward>
In cases like that, the \c[4]Fast Forward\c[0] button becomes
useful to quickly speed through all the text.
However, there are times where the \c[4]Fast Forward\c[0] feature
can be disabled by using the plugin command:
The \c[4]Fast Forward\c[0] feature can be reenabled again also by
Disabling \c[4]Fast Forward\c[0] is useful for things like
cutscenes that should not be sped through.

\c[6]Message Macros\c[0] is an extension plugin made for the
\c[6]Message Core plugin\c[0]. It allows developers to quickly
make easy text codes themselves that translate into
For instance, you can assign to \c[4]\\m\[1]\c[0] the following code:
When used, it will automatically insert that text code in
its place once the macro is detected. It's used here to
You can also use macros through the following text code:
\c[4]\\m\[Harold]\c[0] and have it produce the same effect as using
All macros are defined in the \c[4]Plugin Parameters\c[0]!
\c[6]Message Macros\c[0] is an extension plugin made for the
\c[6]Message Core plugin\c[0]. It allows developers to quickly
make easy text codes themselves that translate into
For instance, you can assign to \c[4]\\m\[1]\c[0] the following code:
When used, it will automatically insert that text code in
its place once the macro is detected. It's used here to
You can also use macros through the following text code:

All macros are defined in the \c[4]Plugin Parameters\c[0]!
These text codes are used to bring out the names and other
related aspects of various database objects.
The \c[4]\\af[x]\c[0] text code allows you to change the face graphic
to that of Actor x. \af[1]This one should be using \c[6]\n[1]\c[0]'s face.
Meanwhile, \c[4]\\ac[x]\c[0] will write out Actor x's current class.
\c[4]\\an[x]\c[0] will write out Actor x's current nickname.
The \c[4]\\p\c[0] versions of the text codes are a bit different. They will
refer to the data of the party member in x position.
For example, \c[4]\\pf[1]\c[0] will show party member 1's face.\pf[1]
\n<Database Object Text Codes>To write out class, item, weapon, armor, skill, and state data,
Those will write out the names of the objects as they appear
\n<Database Object Text Codes>However, you can also draw the icon next to the object name
\c[4]\\ii[x]\c[0] \px[300]Writes out item x's name including icon.
\c[4]\\iw[x]\c[0] \px[300]Writes out weapon x's name including icon.
\c[4]\\ia[x]\c[0] \px[300]Writes out armor x's name including icon.
\c[4]\\is[x]\c[0] \px[300]Writes out skill x's name including icon.
\c[4]\\it[x]\c[0] \px[300]Writes out state x's name including icon.
This makes it easier to write out the acquisition of items
throughout the game. The icon will always be drawn to the
left of the item name like this: \ii[1].
Have fun using these various text codes!

These text codes are used to bring out the names and other
related aspects of various database objects.
The \c[4]\\af[x]\c[0] text code allows you to change the face graphic
to that of Actor x. \af[1]This one should be using \c[6]\n[1]\c[0]'s face.
Meanwhile, \c[4]\\ac[x]\c[0] will write out Actor x's current class.
\c[4]\\an[x]\c[0] will write out Actor x's current nickname.
The \c[4]\\p\c[0] versions of the text codes are a bit different. They will
refer to the data of the party member in x position.
For example, \c[4]\\pf[1]\c[0] will show party member 1's face.\pf[1]
\n<Database Object Text Codes>To write out class, item, weapon, armor, skill, and state data,
Those will write out the names of the objects as they appear
\n<Database Object Text Codes>However, you can also draw the icon next to the object name
\c[4]\\ii[x]\c[0] \px[300]Writes out item x's name including icon.
\c[4]\\iw[x]\c[0] \px[300]Writes out weapon x's name including icon.
\c[4]\\ia[x]\c[0] \px[300]Writes out armor x's name including icon.
\c[4]\\is[x]\c[0] \px[300]Writes out skill x's name including icon.
\c[4]\\it[x]\c[0] \px[300]Writes out state x's name including icon.
This makes it easier to write out the acquisition of items
throughout the game. The icon will always be drawn to the
left of the item name like this: \ii[1].
Have fun using these various text codes!

Letter sounds have been highly demanded. Now the
message system will have it~ Be sure to have fun!
With the \c[6]Extended Message Pack 1\c[0] extension plugin,
you can write out the name of enemies and their position in
their parties just like you can for actors and their current
\c[4]\\en[x]\c[0]\px[300]Gets the name of the enemy in Database position x.
\c[4]\\et[x]\c[0]\px[300]Gets the name of the enemy in Troop position x.
If you use \c[4]\\et[x]\c[0], be sure to use it in battles only.

you can adjust the position of the message window
with more precision with plugin commands.

\c[4]\\msgposy[x] \c[0]\px[400]Sets the Y position of the message window.
\c[4]\\msgwidth[x] \c[0]\px[400]Sets the width of the message window.
\c[4]\\msgrows[x] \c[0]\px[400]Sets the rows of the message window.
will make the message window's width fit
to the size of the text written in it.
same but makes the rows adjust to what's written

With the \c[6]Extended Message Pack 1\c[0] extension plugin,

Previously, are you limited to just the colors that

The \c[4]\\hc[\hc[ff0000]rr\hc[00ff00]gg\hc[0000ff]bb\c[4]]\c[0] text code will change the colors accordingly.\n<Hex Colors>
Replace \hc[ff0000]rr\c[0] with a value between \c[4]00\c[0] and \c[4]ff\c[0] for red.

<WordWrap>Quantity text codes can be used to quickly display the quantity value of an item, weapon, or armor. While this can be done with variables, this is to save the extra step for the times where binding the quantity to a variable isn't possible.
Here, we'll display the quantity values of these items:\n<Extended Message Pack 2>

<WordWrap>Comparison text codes will change the color of the following text based off comparing two number values: x and y. This allows you to make color comparisons without having to create conditional branches for different values.
Let's take a look at how this works:
<WordWrap>Case text codes allow you to choose which words/phrases to be displayed based on whether or not a switch is on/off or a piece of eval code would return true/false.
Let's take a look at how this works:
\c[4]\\caseEval{e?x:y} :\px[500]\c[0]\caseEval{$gameParty.members().length > 3?More than 3 party members:Less than 4 party members}.
<WordWrap>This plugin provides text codes which can display the base parameters, extra parameters, and special parameters of actors and enemies.
Here are the base parameter stats for \c[6]\n[1]\c[0]!\n<Extended Message Pack 2>

<WordWrap>With RPG Maker MV version 1.5.0, you can alter structure of the text codes displayed here to your liking as long as you know a bit of JavaScript. This can be achieved by changing the text code structure within the plugin's parameters.

<WordWrap>It's not uncommon for RPG's to have a \c[4]Message Backlog\c[0], an in-game tool for the player to review any and all dialogue he/she has encountered previously.

<WordWrap>This tool can be helpful in case a player would accidentally skip some dialogue and/or would like to revisit what kind of messages were made before making a decision during an important moment.
<WordWrap>This plugin creates a \c[4]Message Backlog\c[0] for your game's message system.

<WordWrap>Upon pressing '\c[4]Shift\c[0]' (or any other button you desire) during a message, the player can open up a Backlog window to review over the last \c[4]20\c[0] encountered messages (number of stored messages can be modified within the parameters).
<WordWrap>These saved messages can also include any choices from the choice lists they have selected, any numbers they may have inputted, or items they selected from special events.
<WordWrap>Would you like to make some selections to log into the \c[4]Message Backlog\c[0]?
<WordWrap>Here is an example made with a \c[4]Show Choices\c[0] list.
Why are you talking so much?
Why are you talking so much?
And here is an example made with the \c[4]Number Input\c[0], too.
And here is the variable value after it's been changed.
Last but not least, here is an example with a \c[4]Select Item\c[0] event.
And here it is after the player has made a selection.

<WordWrap>Now that I've talked a bunch, you can press '\c[4]Shift\c[0]' to view the \c[4]Message Backlog\c[0]. When it's open, press \c[4]OK\c[0], \c[4]Cancel\c[0], or '\c[4]Shift\c[0]' again to close it.
